characters.name: <synonyms:>
data: <\i{}Lycopodium\i0{} x \i{}issleri\i0{} (Rouy) Domin, \i{}L. complanatum\i0{} auct Brit., \i{}L. alpinum\i0{} var. \i{}decipiens\i0{} Syme. Supposedly = \i{}L. alpinum\i0{} x \i{}L. complanatum\i0{} L.>

states: short and tuberous, with sheathing leaves crowded in dense rosettes
characters.name: stems <elongation>

states: suberect, and rooting <directly> at the base only
creeping, and rooting directly at intervals along their length
creeping, and rooting from characteristic, leafless, root-bearing branches (rhizophores)
characters.name: stems <carriage>

states: ostensibly monopodial vegetatively <owing to unequal development from the original dichotomies>
characters.name: stems <manner of branching>

states: dorsiventrally organized, with four ranks of leaves
characters.name: stems <whether dorsiventral>

states: with anomalous secondary thickening <via a cambium external to the primary phloem, producing small quantities of vascular tissue centripetally, and generating centrifugally large quantities of so-called prismatic tissue, comprising a mixture of xylem, phloem and parenchyma>
characters.name: stems <presence of secondary thickening>

states: persistent on the stem, short and blackish, each with two long points
characters.name: the old leaf bases <in \i{}Isoetes\i0{}, persistence>

states: of two kinds: those of the two ranks on the upper side of the stem appressed and directed towards the stem apex, and those of the two lower ranks larger and spreading laterally
characters.name: <foliage> leaves <heterophylly>

states: differing markedly from the foliage leaves
characters.name: sporophylls <modified or leaflike>

states: aggregated into well defined terminal cones
in fertile zones tending to alternate with sterile zones along the stems, rather than in well defined terminal cones
characters.name: sporophylls <arrangement>

states: sessile at the tips of the normal shoots
on long, erect peduncles which bear distant, appressed, scale-like leaves
characters.name: cones <carriage>

states: basal and subsessile on the adaxial surfaces of the sporophylls, non-septate
very large, transversely and longitudinally septate and embedded in the leaf bases
characters.name: the sporangia

states: with a reticulate ornamentation, neither tuberculate nor spiny
characters.name: the megaspores <of Isoetes, surface ornamentation>
<distribution in the British Isles:>
data: <rather common throughout the British Isles, especially at higher elevations>
<curiously, the supposed parental species \i{}L. complanatum\i0{} is no longer listed as British, it now being assumed that early records represent the hybrid>
<throughout the British Isles, common in mountains but rare and decreasing in lowland regions>
<with a western distribution: E. Cornwall, S. Devon, Dorset, Glamorgan, Merioneth, Caernarvon>
<Wales, Shropshire, S.E. Yorkshire, Lake District, Scotland from Perth Northwards to Shetland, in Ireland mainly western>
<throughout the British Isles, but local, rare in S. Scotland, Wales and N.E. England>
<local in England and Scotland, extinct in Wales and absent from Ireland(?)>
<throughout the British Isles, but scarce in lowland areas>
<commonly grown in greenhouses, naturalized in Cornwall, Ireland and perhaps elsewhere>
<widespread and rather common on high ground in England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland, ascending to about 1000 m>

characters.name: <general comments:>
data: <more robust in habit than \i{}D. alpinum\i0{}, and more glaucous>
<the megaspores are non-functional, reproduction being via bud-like gemmae produced in the leaf axils>

<interest in extinct Lycopsida  .... has centred largely on the Carboniferous members of the group because of the abundance of fossils, the diversity of forms they exhibit, and their arborescent habit. Some of them vie in size with all but the largest of modern forest trees, and the fossil record indicates that they grew in more or less pure stands. As a result, they enter our economy today as important contributors of the raw material that became coal" (Andrews (1961). Rermarkably, however, fossil remains of plants morphologically and anatomically very similar to extant \i{}Lycopodium\i0{} occurred much earlier in the Paleozoic, as exemplified by \i{}Baragwanathia longifolia\i0{} from the Silurian of Australia, and by \i{}Lycopodites\i0{} from the Carboniferous and Mesozoic. Heterosporous, herbaceous plants closely comparable with present day \i{}Selaginella\i0{}, variously referred to \i{}Selaginellites\i0{} and even to \i{}Selaginella\i0{} itself, also occur in Paleozoic and Mesozoic deposits; and it is clear from the fossil record that the genus \i{}Isoetes\i0{} was represented in essentially its present form by the mid-Cretaceous. While the spectacular arborescent lycopods which dominated Carboniferous forests disappeared around the end of that epoch, their herbaceous relatives have shown extraordinary resilience>

images.n: 1765, \i{}Diphasiastrum\i0{} (\i{}Lycopodium\i0{}) \i{}clavatum\i0{}; 1766, \i{}Lycopodium annotinum\i0{}; 1767, \i{}Diphasiastrum\i0{} (\i{}Lycopodium\i0{}) \i{}alpinum\i0{}; 1768, \i{}Huperzia\i0{} (\i{}Lycopodium\i0{}) \i{}selago\i0{}; 1769, \i{}Lycopodiella\i0{} (\i{}Lycopodium\i0{}) \i{}inundata\i0{}; 1770, \i{}Selaginella selaginoides\i0{}. 1762, \i{}Isoetes lacustris\i0{} L. (with a megaspore); 1763, \i{}I. echinospora\i0{} Durieu (showing spiny megaspore); 1764, \i{}I. histrix\i0{} Bory (showing persistent old leaf bases and a megaspore). From Sowerby and Johnson (1863).
\i{}Isoetes setacea\i0{} Lam. is a mainland-European species. From Le Maout and Decaisne (1873).
